content:
In this PR, we proved that injectivity, surjectivity, bijectivity and exactness are local properties using LocalizedModule. More precisely, we showed that these can be checked at maximal ideals and on standard covers. And we use these to prove that flatness is a local property in #19085.
@Christian Merten suggested us to formulate all these lemmas for an arbitrary family of module satisfying the correct IsLocalizedModule predicate. (Like the setup in LocalProperties.Submodule)
@Junyan Xu told us he's able to get rid of Rₚ in LocalProperties/Submodule by introducing Submodule.localized₀ which is a submodule over the base ring rather than the localization in #19118.
Which of the three setups should we use?
I think the settings IsLocalization and IsLocalizedModule are more general, but the theorems are more complicated and harder to apply. I'm not sure which is better.

I believe we prefer IsLocalizedModule for flexible applicability, and if you are feeling generous you can provide both. You can provide the IsLocalizedModule versions only for your end results if that makes things easier.

I need the theorems like Submodule.eq_of_localization_maximal to prove the version for IsLocalization and IsLocalizedModule, but in #19118 they will be changed from Submodule.localized' to Submodule.localized₀?

If I understand Junyan's suggestion correctly, the Submodule.localized' versions will stay, directly derived from the Submodule.localized₀ version, so it should not make a difference for the proofs in the exactness file, which is the one I suggested to generalize to the IsLocalizedModule setting.
Membership and ≤ in localized₀ is defeq to membership in localized', but equality isn't. So it might be a good idea to provide localized' version only for the submodule equality lemmas ...
